Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Increasing Wheat Yield Through Enhanced Plant Architecture
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project aims to increase yield in wheat by using TILLING, a reverse genetics tool, to identify novel alleles of candidate wheat yield genes in tetraploid and hexaploid wheat. In crops such as wheat with more complex genome structures and less advanced genomic tools, the major genes underlying many aspects of plant architecture are yet to be identified. However, due to functional conservation, genes regulating traits in rice (and other crops) are likely to play similar roles in wheat. Once new alleles of these genes have been identified they will be subsequently evaluated for the ability to alter wheat architecture and improve yield in the greenhouse and in the field. As a non-GM technology, products from TILLING can rapidly advance to commercialization and do not face market or regulatory restrictions.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project, if successful, will be the economic impact of improved wheat yields. The U.S. is the largest wheat exporter globally, yet the competitiveness of U.S. wheat, both globally and domestically, is declining significantly. Planted acreage is down thirty percent since the 1980s, in large part due to competition from other crops with higher returns. Net returns to farmers from wheat are consistently half or less than that from corn and soy. With a conservative 5% increase in yield resulting from this project, the yearly value creation to the U.S. farmer is estimated at over $30/hectare. In addition, the value of higher yielding wheat varieties to a seed company arising from this research in the U.S. alone is more than $40 million annually. By incorporating favorable alleles of plant architecture genes into a commercial wheat breeding program, it is believed that this project will make a significant contribution to improving the competitiveness of U.S. wheat.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The U.S. is the largest wheat exporter globally, yet the competitiveness of U.S. wheat, both globally and domestically, is declining significantly. Planted acreage is down thirty percent since the 1980s, in large part due to competition from other crops with higher returns.  Net returns to farmers from wheat are consistently half or less than that from corn and soy. Further, the rate of growth in wheat yield has stalled and historically has grown at one fourth that of corn. The Economic Research Service posits that genetic improvement of wheat has been slower due to the complexity of the wheat genome and the lower value capture opportunities for the private sector from investments in research (USDA Wheat Baseline 2012-21).  The competitiveness of U.S. wheat will depend upon reversing these trends, including stimulating yield growth rates through private sector investment. 

 

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project aims to increase yield in wheat by using TILLING, a reverse genetics tool, to identify novel alleles of candidate wheat yield genes in tetraploid and hexaploid wheat. As natural resources diminish and the human population grows it is increasingly important to improve crop yield per unit area. This is especially true for a staple cereal crop such as wheat. In cereals, final grain yield is a complex trait that is a combination of grain number, average grain weight, grain size, tiller number and plant height. While the 1960’s green revolution took advantage of dwarfing genes to improve yield, more recently an increasing number of loci responsible for other aspects of yield are being identified through quantitative trait locus (QTL) analysis. In rice (and other crops) with advanced genomics tools, the genes underlying these yield QTLs are being identified (Bai et al, 2012). The focus of these recent studies has been on identifying genes affecting other aspects of plant architecture such as grain number per panicle, grain size and tiller number per plant. In crops with more complex genome structures and less advanced genomic tools, such as tetraploid (Kronos) and hexaploid (Express) wheat, the major genes underlying these plant architecture QTLs are slow to be identified (McIntyre et al, 2010). However due to functional conservation, genes regulating traits in rice (and other crops) are likely to play similar roles in wheat. With the aim of increasing yield in wheat, we are using TILLING (McCallum et al, 2000) to identify novel alleles of five candidate wheat yield genes in tetraploid and hexaploid wheat. During Phase I research we identified a large number of new alleles in our target genes which are summarized in Table 1. 

 

A subset of these new alleles will be subsequently evaluated for the ability to alter wheat architecture and improve yield in the greenhouse and in the field. Following successful field trials, Arcadia will license these technologies for commercialization through one or more of our current wheat partners.  By incorporating favorable alleles of plant architecture genes into a wheat breeding program we believe that we can make a significant contribution to improving yield in this staple food crop.  As a non-GM technology, products from TILLING can rapidly advance to commercialization and do not face market or regulatory restrictions. With a conservative 5% increase in yield, the yearly value creation to the U.S. farmer is estimated at over $30/hectare. In addition, the value of higher yielding wheat varieties to a seed company arising from this research in the U.S. alone is more than $40 million annually. In summary, by incorporating favorable alleles of plant architecture genes into a commercial wheat breeding program we believe we can make a significant contribution to improving yield in this vital food crop.
